Qaeda Suspect's Bosnian Wife Says He's No Terrorist

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1363 words

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Jan. 27


Her husband came to Bosnia in late 1995 as an Islamic missionary and, Anela
Belkacem says, to marry a Bosnian woman. What he did for the previous four years
is a little foggy. She confirmed that he had arrived here on a forged Yemeni
passport.

But she said that does not make her husband, Bansayah Belkacem, a top operative
of Al Qaeda in Europe. American officials charged that he was, after he and five
other Algerians were deported a week ago and turned over to the Americans, who
transported them to the naval prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

Ms. Belkacem said she never even saw her husband with a mobile phone: how then
could he have made repeated cellular calls to one of Osama bin Laden's top aides
after Sept. 11, as United States officials allege?

"He never had one," she said in the only detailed interview she has granted. "He
doesn't have a car or a satellite dish. That would be very odd for a Qaeda
member."

She is angry, but so are many other Bosnian Muslims who do not have her personal
stake in the arrest of the so-called Algerian Six. And to many, whether the men
are guilty is almost beside the point.

The painful memories of the war from 1992 to 1995 that destroyed Bosnia are
entwining themselves tightly here into America's new war on terrorism. The
issues are many, and they include allegations that the United States ran
roughshod over Bosnia's fragile justice system in gaining custody of the men.

But the emotional core for many Bosnian Muslims is this: why did the United
States act so quickly against six Muslim men but lag in the cases against
Radovan Karadzic, the wartime Bosnian Serb leader, and Ratko Mladic, the top
Bosnian Serb general, both still at large though they were indicted in 1995 for
war crimes against Bosnian Muslims?

Several Bosnian and international experts say the anger runs deep and threatens
to chip away at support for the United States among Bosnia's Muslims, who are
largely pro-Western and are mostly moderate in their religious practices.

Their support, experts say, is vital because of the numbers of Islamic activists
here, like Mr. Belkacem, and because of fears that Bosnia may become a breeding
ground for extremism.

"For principled reasons, and also for political reasons, it should not appear
that the international community is biased," Wolfgang Petritsch, the chief
administrator for international organizations here in Bosnia, said in an
interview.

The deportations of the six Algerians, he said, should "motivate us to move
against Karadzic now."

In fact, there does seem to be something of a renewed effort to arrest the two
men, though it is impossible to tell how serious that effort is after years of
stalling and disagreements among Western nations about what to do about them.

It is widely assumed that Dr. Karadzic moves around Bosnia, possibly staying in
Orthodox monasteries, and in the neighboring Yugoslav republic of Montenegro,
while General Mladic reportedly hides in Belgrade, the capital of both
Yugoslavia and its larger republic, Serbia.

Last week an official in Washington described a "redoubling" of efforts to catch
the two men but would not be more specific. Also last week, the American Embassy
here plastered the capital, Sarajevo, with posters offering up to $5 million for
information leading to the arrest of Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic. Eventually
posters will be put up around Bosnia, officials said.

Karen Williams, spokeswoman for the embassy, said the poster campaign had been
planned long ago and was not aimed at diluting anger over the deportation of the
Algerians.

"It has nothing to do with the six guys -- categorically," she said.

Bosnian officials arrested the six Algerians in early October, saying they were
planning attacks on the United States Embassy as well as on the American
military here, which includes 3,100 American soldiers as part of the broader
effort to keep the peace in Bosnia.

Of the six, five had Bosnian citizenship and one was a permanent resident. All
were married, including one with two wives. Most arrived after the war, but at
least one fought beside the Bosnian Muslims in the war, as did many men who came
from Muslim countries for that purpose.

Several knew each other in Algeria, and all have worked for Islamic relief
groups, which are often considered centers for a more fundamentalist form of
Islam.

Mr. Belkacem, 39, was singled out by American officials, who said they had
monitored phone calls between him and Abu Zubaydah, the operations chief of Al
Qaeda, believed to be one of a handful of men entrusted with running the
terrorism network in the event of Osama bin Laden's death or capture.

Bosnian officials recovered phone lists from his home in Zenica, where many
Muslim militants live, with what they said was Mr. Zubaydah's phone number in
Pakistan.

More recently, American investigators have described Mr. Belkacem as one of Mr.
bin Laden's chief lieutenants in Europe -- and the men's presence in Bosnia as a
"credible threat."

Little is known otherwise about Mr. Belkacem, and he has provided little
information since his arrest, though he was interrogated twice by American
officials here.

His lawyer, Nermina Pivic, said he left Algeria in 1991 to go on a pilgrimage to
Saudi Arabia. She said he stayed there, moving between Mecca and Medina, until
1995, when he saw an advertisement for Islamic missionaries in Bosnia.

His wife said that she did not have a precise accounting for how he had spent
those years, but that he had not visited Afghanistan or Pakistan. Using a fake
Yemeni passport -- his lawyer said he had obtained it because he had lost his
Algerian passport -- he arrived in Bosnia in November 1995.

The war was ending, so he did not fight. He went to work for an Islamic relief
group, the Balkan Islamic Center in Zenica.

Esad Hecimovic, a reporter in Zenica for Dani, a respected weekly magazine, who
has investigated Mr. Belkacem, said: "Everyone who worked at the Balkan Islamic
Center shared a package of beliefs. It's the standard: anti-Western,
anti-Israeli, conspiracy theories against Islam."

But he said Mr. Belkacem had not drawn particular attention, and even now he
said it was difficult to piece together a picture of him and his activities.
Bosnian authorities forced the group to close down in 1997, the same year Mr.
Belkacem was married. Since then, his wife said, he has supported her and their
two young daughters by selling perfume and silver.

Despite his strong religious beliefs, she said, he did not force Islam on
others, not even on her.

"He didn't tell me to cover my face or my hair," said Mrs. Belkacem, 27, whose
head and face are veiled. "It was my choice."

She said he never mentioned Osama bin Laden, did not socialize much, never
received phone calls from abroad and never called anyone outside Bosnia except
his family in Algeria. His landlords in Zenica said they had noticed nothing
unusual in the six months he lived in their three-unit apartment building off a
main road in Zenica.

They said they believed that the arrest was unfair, particularly since Dr.
Karadzic and General Mladic were still free.

"It irritates us," said Dzemila Alajbegovic, 46, who owns the building with her
husband. "Everyone knows there is proof of what Karadzic and Mladic have done.
But this man, as far as I know, there is no evidence."

Nadja Dizdarevic, the wife of Boudella Hadz, 36, another of the deported
Algerians, said that "someone is just playing with the law in Bosnia."

The Bosnian government has acknowledged that the United States exerted heavy
pressure to hand over the men. Rather than extraditing them, a more complicated
legal procedure, Bosnian officials stripped them of their citizenship and
deported them on Oct. 18.

The day before, both Bosnia's highest court and the top human rights panel
ordered the men's release for lack of evidence that they were planning a
terrorist attack, though not ending further investigation.

Human rights groups, including the top United Nations human rights advocate
here, criticized the deportation. Dani magazine, which has written strongly
against Islamic fundamentalists in Bosnia, ran a cover depicting Uncle Sam
urinating on Bosnia's Constitution.

Forgotten Prisoners of War

BYLINE:  By Jennifer Leaning and John Heffernan; Jennifer Leaning, a physician,
is a professor at the Harvard School of Public Health and a board member of
Physicians for Human Rights. John Heffernan is a consultant to Physicians for
Human Rights.

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Editorial Desk; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 521 words

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.


While the world's attention has been focused on the living conditions and legal
status of Qaeda suspects in Guantanamo Bay, a much larger group of Taliban
prisoners in Afghanistan is at risk of dying in detention. Some 3,500 Afghan and
Pakistani Taliban men are being held in dangerously squalid conditions in the
Shebarghan prison in northern Afghanistan. In our visit to the prison on Jan.
20, we found cell blocks designed for 20 prisoners holding up to 100 men; 8 to
10 toilets for each 1,000 men; bathing facilities outdoors in the mud; and
grossly inadequate food and medical care. Dysentery is epidemic. The prison's
commander, General Jarobak, told us that "many, many, many men" had already
died.

The American military knows about these conditions and has a duty under
international law to ensure that the prisoners are treated humanely. This
obligation falls on both the Afghan government and the United States, which led
the war in Afghanistan. Regardless of whether the United States captured these
prisoners or has actual custody of them, it shares with the Afghan government
responsibility for their decent care.

General Jarobak, who said he reported to Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, deputy
defense minister in the interim government of Hamid Karzai, seemed genuinely
distressed by the deplorable situation at Shebarghan and appealed to us to ask
the United States and other donors for assistance. He said that he had already
submitted requests for further assistance and resources to the international
community but the response had been minimal. The month-old government of Mr.
Karzai does not have the resources even to continue its current spending for the
upkeep of the prison, much less to raise standards in conformity with
international law.

To our knowledge, we were the first human rights observers to enter the
facility. But we were not the prisoners' first visitors. Until mid-January, the
American military controlled access and American officers interviewed the
captives. They took away the prisoners whom they wished to interrogate further.

The rest remain at Shebarghan, where more will die unless help is promptly
offered. There is almost nothing in Afghanistan that doesn't require
international assistance. After conducting health assessments in Mazar-i-Sharif
and Kabul as well as at the prison, we came away staggered by the enormity of
the destruction, suffering and need in this ruined land. But a great military
power like the United States has a particular obligation to care for captured
combatants whose fate it is in a position to influence.

The United States, as leader of the coalition forces, should work with its
allies, the Afghan government and the United Nations to provide resources to
remedy these prison conditions and to determine as soon as possible the legal
status of these prisoners, any charges against them and the judicial process
required to resolve their cases. Beyond Shebarghan prison, the Afghan government
needs help carrying out a census of military detainees and prisoners of war and
acting to assure that conditions of confinement meet international standards.

Khmer Rouge Trials Won't Be Fair, Critics Say

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS

SECTION: Section 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 854 words

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 9


Cambodians said today that they felt betrayed and abandoned after the United
Nations gave up its effort to create an international tribunal to try former
leaders of the Khmer Rouge.

Worn down by the stubbornness of the Cambodian government, the United Nations
said on Friday that it was ending nearly five years of negotiations over the
makeup and procedures of the tribunal.

This leaves the government to proceed on its own with trials that both Cambodian
and foreign analysts say will not meet international standards of fairness and
impartiality and are likely to spare most major figures.

"This is a victory for Pol Pot and the top leaders of the Khmer Rouge regime,"
said Kao Kim Hourn, a leading Cambodian political analyst. "This is the end of
the possibility of bringing to justice the people who were responsible for
crimes against humanity in Cambodia."

The radical communist Khmer Rouge, led by Pol Pot, were responsible for the
deaths of more than a million people when they held power from 1975 to 1979. Pol
Pot died in 1998.

As international tribunals have been set up to bring justice for more recent
atrocities in Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia, the Cambodian government has
stymied one attempt after another by the United Nations to create a tribunal
here.

"This is the outcome they wanted," a Western diplomat said today. "The
government never wanted United Nations interference. They want something they
can control, and now they are getting it."

He said the objections of China, a long-term sponsor of the Khmer Rouge, played
a decisive role in holding Cambodia back from an agreement.

Left to its own devices, most analysts say, the government is likely to pick and
choose any future defendants and to hand down preordained sentences as it has in
previous politically important trials.

"I think a real trial with genuine justice will not be possible if the United
Nations stays with its decision not to participate," said Youk Chhang, director
of the Documentation Center of Cambodia, which has been collecting documentary
evidence against Khmer Rouge leaders.

"This is not only about Cambodia but about humanity; the government and the
United Nations bear equal responsibility to work on this issue," he said. "So
just saying, 'Sorry, goodbye, wish you luck' -- you are undermining the rule of
law and international integrity."

Once again, Cambodia finds itself a sideshow, as it did during the Vietnam war,
Mr. Kao Kim Hourn said. Now it is the war on terror that is preoccupying the
attention of world.

"The shifting of the focus of the United Nations to Afghanistan and other areas
has overshadowed Cambodia," he said, "and now the United Nations is just washing
its hands of Cambodia.

"So from now on, Ieng Sary and the other top leaders can live out their lives
safely and happily," he said. Mr. Ieng Sary, one of the key surviving leaders,
is likely to be protected by an ad hoc amnesty issued by the government,
analysts said.

Other leaders who may escape indictment are Khieu Samphan and Nuon Chea, top
confidants of Pol Pot who surrendered at the end of 1998 and were welcomed with
an embrace by Prime Minister Hun Sen.

At the time, Mr. Hun Sen suggested that Cambodia "dig a hole and bury the past."
He has remained coy about the prospects for trials.

If Cambodia does proceed with trials, two likely defendants will be Ta Mok, a
brutal military chief, and Kaing Kek Ieu, known as Duch, who ran the Tuol Sleng
torture center. They are the only former Khmer Rouge leaders now in custody.

"He has no love for any of these people," a European diplomat said. "But there
is still the lingering doubt that if he cannot control the trial, it could
produce some evidence that would be embarrassing either for people close to him
or for himself."

Mr. Hun Sen was a low-level commander for the Khmer Rouge who defected and
participated in their ouster by an invading Vietnamese force in 1979.
Researchers have found no evidence that he was involved in atrocities.

In announcing its withdrawal from the negotiations, the United Nations said the
Cambodian framework for trials, embodied in a new law, left too many loopholes.
The government said its law was non-negotiable and could not be modified.

Cambodian officials said today they would proceed on their own.

"No problem at all," said Sok An, the cabinet minister who has led the
negotiations on the Cambodian side.

The United States, which has worked with Cambodia on a complex model that would
use a combination of foreign and local judges and prosecutors, said it was
disappointed by the United Nations pullout.

American diplomats have been among those who argue that a less-than-perfect
trial is better than no trial at all. With the former Khmer Rouge leaders
growing older and more frail, the diplomats argue, it is important to seize this
last chance to bring them to account.

Others, like Kek Galabru, a leading human rights advocate here, say an imperfect
trial would set a dangerous precedent for the future. "If it cooperated with
such a tribunal that doesn't meet international standards, the United Nations
will lose all credibility," she said today.

Liberia Rounds Up Youths

BYLINE:  Reuters

SECTION: Section A; Column 4; Foreign Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 144 words

DATELINE: MONROVIA, Liberia, Feb. 11


In a roundup that it justified by a state of emergency, the government has put
scores of street youths in jail, officials said today.

The city, Liberia's capital, was frequently the scene of deadly street fighting
during a civil war in the 1990's. It has been on edge since rebels struck 22
miles away on Thursday.

Security forces have since driven the rebels back. But the police said they had
locked up the youths for terrorizing residents and would keep them until their
parents came. The human rights group Amnesty International accused President
Charles Taylor's forces of using the emergency as a cover for rights violations,
including forcible recruitment.

Liberia's return to chaos has raised concerns in neighboring Sierra Leone, where
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, over the weekend, hailed efforts that
ended a war by Liberian-backed rebels.

DEFIANT, MILOSEVIC BEGINS HIS DEFENSE BY ASSAILING NATO

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER and MARLISE SIMONS

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1293 words

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, Feb. 14


A driven and indignant Slobodan Milosevic today laid blame for a decade of
carnage in the Balkans on everyone but himself, waving away charges that he was
responsible for war crimes in four words: "It is all lies."

"The real crime," he added, "was the killing of Yugoslavia and crucifying me
here."

In a dramatic and tense four-hour statement, Mr. Milosevic, largely unpopular at
home, seemed to seize a new political mission in his trial here: to defend
himself, and fellow Serbs, by attacking NATO and casting himself as an
antiglobalist hero resisting the double standards of the world's powers. He even
turned President Bush's epithet -- "evil-doers" -- back onto the West.

"The Americans go right to the other side of the globe to fight against
terrorism -- Afghanistan a case in point," Mr. Milosevic told his judges, with
finger jabs and a confidence that left no doubt that this is a man used to his
authority. "And that is considered to be logical and normal. Whereas here the
struggle against terrorism, in the heart of one's own country, in one's own home
is considered to be a crime."

The first head of state to be tried for war crimes, Mr. Milosevic today also
turned much conventional history on its head. He denied that his troops killed
thousands of civilians in Kosovo in 1999, as prosecutors in the United Nations
tribunal allege, saying they only fought a war against Albanian separatist
"terrorists."

Civilian killings in Kosovo, he said, were carried out by ethnic Albanian rebels
or by NATO planes, which bombed Serbia and Kosovo for 78 days in 1999.

In the spectators' gallery, Nekibe Kelmendi watched, pale and tense, appalled at
Mr. Milosevic's version of the truth. Her husband, a prominent human rights
lawyer, and their two sons were found dead in Kosovo at the start of the war
after being arrested by Serbian secret police.

"I feel sick to my stomach listening to all his lies," said Ms. Kelmendi, a
judge who served as minister of justice for Kosovo after the war. "When I look
at Milosevic, I see a killer."

In his testimony today, Mr. Milosevic also engaged in a duel of images,
producing photographs and videos that were even more ghastly than those shown by
prosecutors earlier this week, this time of the victims of NATO airstrikes. At
his request, courtroom monitors flashed images of bombed sites, charred and
mangled bodies and severed human limbs and heads.

"The bombing of civilian targets was merciless," he said solemnly. "The more
suffering of civilians, the better."

For his indictments accusing him of crimes in three wars, he showed only
contempt, describing them variously as a "terrible fabrication," a "nebulous
construction" and a "miserable opus."

Court officials said they had expected Mr. Milosevic to focus on NATO, since
that had been the underlying theme of earlier outbursts in the court. During Mr.
Milosevic's speech, which was well-prepared, delivered in Serbian and is to
continue on Friday, Carla Del Ponte, the chief prosecutor, occasionally shot a
smile at other prosecutors in apparent incredulity. Ms. Del Ponte's spokeswoman,
Florence Hartmann, said that however awful the civilian deaths caused by NATO,
"what he presented today was not a defense."

Mr. Milosevic, the leader of the Serbs for 13 years, is charged with genocide
against Bosnian Muslims in the war in Bosnia-Herzegovina, from 1992 to 1995, and
with other crimes from the wars in Croatia in 1991 and Kosovo in 1999. The first
part of the trial is devoted to Kosovo -- an order that gave Mr. Milosevic the
opportunity to focus his own attack on NATO.

In earlier court appearances, he said he did not recognize the tribunal and
therefore would not appoint lawyers to defend him. But after his speech today, a
more immediate reason emerged: he clearly wanted to speak for himself.

With today's session, the third day of a trial that may last two years, he also
achieved what had been his goal since his arrival in The Hague in June: the
transformation of the courtroom into his political platform.

Seated in a navy suit and a tie with the red, white and blue colors of the
Serbian flag, Mr. Milosevic made his case by working his way down a stack of
papers several inches high.

Almost surely aware that his trial is drawing a fascinated television audience
at home among admirers and victims, Mr. Milosevic seemed to be largely
addressing Serbs, casting himself as fighter and victim against forces far
larger than himself, a recurring theme in Serbian history.

"There is not a single element of a fair trial or of equality between these
parties," he complained. "There is an enormous apparatus on one side," he said.
"Everything is at your disposal. What is on my side? I only have a public
telephone booth in the prison."

The trial is being covered extensively in Yugoslavia, and even his opponents in
Serbia may be pleased with his outrage against the widely resented NATO
bombings.

More than that, he seems to be looking to his place in Serbian history, linking
his fate at the tribunal with that of all Serbs by tapping into what he called
the "sensitive" question of collective guilt.

"In all the indictments, they are accusing a whole nation," he said. "Such dirty
crimes cannot be ascribed to an army, a police, a people, a nation, their
government."

It is unclear if he believes it possible to be found innocent, but he spent much
time rebutting specific accusations and snipping the connections that
prosecutors made in their opening statements between him and the atrocities
across the Serbian border in Bosnia and Croatia.

One man alone, he ridiculed, could not possibly do all the things prosecutors
allege.

"He probably thinks that I am superhuman, having these superhuman powers of
influencing people and responsibility and accountability outside the territory
of my country," he said. "He has ascribed to me some magical, God-like powers."

While he did not address the worst atrocity of the war -- the massacre of 7,000
Bosnian Muslims in Srebrenica -- he specifically distanced himself from other
serious accusations.

He said he regularly condemned the shelling of Sarajevo by Bosnian Serbs, which
claimed an estimated 10,000 lives. He also said he was lied to about the
existence of concentration camps in northwestern Bosnia in 1992.

"When I heard there were some camps, I asked for an explanation: 'Is it possible
Serbs were setting up any camps?' " he said. "The explanation I received was the
following: 'There were no camps. There were only prisons for prisoners of war.'
"

From his stack of papers, he showed dozens of photographs, of bombed factories,
houses, bridges, a train and a convoy of Albanians to make his case that NATO
was equally responsible for civilian deaths in the Balkans.

While some 4,000 corpses have been unearthed in Kosovo, most of them Albanian,
Human Rights Watch estimates that NATO bombings killed at least 500 civilians,
acts which it said violated the Geneva Conventions but did not rise to the level
of war crime. Mr. Milosevic disagreed, asking when NATO would be tried for the
bombing.

"This aggression shows that the NATO pact was not an alliance but an appendage
of the American administration, which used it as it deemed when it deemed fit,"
he said.

The reason, he said, "was the geo-strategic spreading of NATO's interests and
its areas and also to create a precedent for using force."

And he asked to be set free, at least during the trial, so he could prepare
himself properly.

"You know full well I am not going to escape," he said. "Let me go free so that
as a free man I can take an active stand in this regard. You want us to engage
in a swimming competition -- 100 meters -- but you want to tie my hands and feet
and let me swim that way and you consider that to be a fair trial."

The Pointed Finger

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER

SECTION: Section 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 965 words

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, Feb. 16


In the Balkans, where the wars were often fought from house to house, among
neighbors, candid Serbs often say, yes, our people committed war crimes, but we
were not the only ones. In civil war, all are guilty.

By making NATO the focus of his own defense, Slobodan Milosevic, the former
Yugoslav leader, has extended that justification a distinct notch: you in the
West, he says, with your nice homes and radar-skirting bombers -- you, too, are
bloodied. For two days, he presented his evidence: photo after photo of what the
United States military calls "collateral damage," people killed by NATO bombs.

"This is the corpse of Ljiljana Specic," Mr. Milosevic, on trial here for
genocide and other war crimes, said on Friday morning. "She was seven months
pregnant. She was killed on a street corner."

It might comfort some to dismiss Mr. Milosevic as a lunatic, but his performance
is deliberate. His defense taps into real grievances of Serbs, the lack of easy
solutions in the Balkans, palpable misgivings among other poor nations about the
extent of American power -- if twisted surreally to deny any blame at all for
himself. He is raving with a purpose, as he always has.

"He's not crazy," said Richard Dicker, a lawyer with Human Rights Watch, who has
been attending the trial. "What we have heard in the last two days is a very
shrewd, canny political offensive. Indeed he's trying to turn everything upside
down, casting himself as the victim, NATO as the criminal and the court as
accomplice to the crime.

"He speaks as if he's the prince of peace," he added. "That to me is the
ultimate cynicism."

Of course, it is Mr. Milosevic, not NATO, who is on trial, so little of his
broadside is likely to help him in court, where he is the first head of state to
be tried for genocide. (He is not the first head of state to be tried for war
crimes: that was Adm. Karl Donitz, who led Germany for just more than a week
after Hitler died. He spent 10 years in prison.)

While he blames others, in opening statements where both sides are allowed much
oratorical latitude, prosecutors will bring witnesses to try to show that he had
direct command responsibility for some of the worst horrors of the late 20th
century: more than 200,000 killed, more than 2 million uprooted from their homes
in "ethnic cleansing," the imponderable execution of 7,000 Bosnian Muslims who
lived in Srebrenica.

They must prove that Mr. Milosevic "knew or had reason to know" what
subordinates did and that he himself either did nothing to prevent crimes or let
them go unpunished.

In their opening statements, Carla Del Ponte, the tribunal's chief prosecutor,
and her team spent two days showing how they intended to do that.

For the wars in Croatia and in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the prosecutors have
tried to show financial, military and political links between Mr. Milosevic and
Serbs in those states to create a "Greater Serbia." By then, Croatia and Bosnia
had broken off from Yugoslavia, so Mr. Milosevic was not in legal command there.

The prosecutors have not yet, for these two wars, produced a smoking gun. For
that, Ms. Del Ponte says she will produce inside witnesses, people close to Mr.
Milosevic.

Like Mr. Milosevic, she also emphasized the global scope of the trial, but in a
different way. Although she did not identify the countries, she said nations
that so far had been unwilling to allow sensitive intelligence to be used in
court must begin to do so to ensure Mr. Milosevic's conviction. Her words, by
implication, pointed to the United States and Britain.

"People throughout the world following these proceedings will be watching to see
the extent to which their own leaders are committed to achieving the aims of
international justice," she said in court on Tuesday, the first day of the
trial.

The 1999 war in Kosovo, a part of Serbia, may be a different matter: Mr.
Milosevic had actual control of Serbian forces there. The prosecution will have
to prove it was those forces that deported 850,000 Kosovo Albanians and killed
more than 5,000 of them.

On Kosovo, Mr. Milosevic counters with what most historians would say is an
outrageous claim: that NATO bombs and Albanian rebels did the killing and the
rousting.

An unanswerable question is whether he believes that. Serbian journalists,
seeing Mr. Milosevic in action up close for the first time, say they are stunned
to think that he may well have convinced himself.

Either way, it allows him to make his points, however irrelevant they may be to
his defense and certainly no justification for mass killings. But they are not
necessarily irrelevant in a broader sense. "And you call yourselves a tribunal,"
he chided the court on Friday and so questioned the right of "international
justice" to try him.

In a similar way, the United States has balked at the idea of a permanent
international criminal court, for fear its own military leaders would be
unfairly tried before a sometimes hostile world.

He presented a bone-chilling demonstration of what the "collateral damage" of
NATO bombs looks like -- at a time when many people are uncomfortable, after the
damage of stray bombs in Afghanistan, about what it really means to fight from
15,000 feet.

His complaints about reverse ethnic cleansing of Serbs in Kosovo, after NATO
arrived in 1999, by long-aggrieved ethnic Albanians, along with the worries
about Albanian organized crime, are shared by many thoughtful Balkans experts.

Mr. Milosevic sees his trial not strictly as a way to defend himself. This man
-- who rarely gave interviews, who in a decade of war did not visit Serbian
refugees or fighters -- is now claiming the role of a soldier of truth. He is
speaking, as he often put it this week, to "the public."

As one former judge here said: "It's going to be a unique trial."

Where the Bodies Are Buried in Peru

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1279 words

DATELINE: QUISPILLACTA, Peru, Feb. 16


For 19 years, Cristina Huamani Quispe knew where her husband was buried, just up
the dirt road from this Quechua Indian hamlet, in a shallow grave were his
bullet-riddled body was tossed with those of six other men.

But Mrs. Huamani, 46, never sought help from the authorities because an army
patrol had killed the men after accusing them of being members of Shining Path,
a radical rebel group. She could not recover the body of her husband, Pedro
Nunez, fearing retribution from soldiers. So she simply tried to forget.

"I could not do anything," she recalled in Quechua, speaking through an
interpreter. "I always felt alone. I would just cry."

Now, 15 months after the fall of the autocratic government of President Alberto
K. Fujimori, a special government commission is opening a window into 20 years
of state-sponsored repression and rebel terror that tore this country apart. It
is starting the emotionally wrenching process of investigating the killings and
disappearances of thousands of people, many of them from this province,
Ayacucho.

The group has begun interviewing relatives of victims here in southern Peru and
disinterring the remains of Mr. Nunez and the six other men, who were buried
here on May 14, 1983, at the height of the violence.

Taking advantage of a political opening that would have been unthinkable a short
time ago, the commission will collect testimony in private and hold public
hearings, a first in Latin America, where victims of violence and public
officials can give their accounts.

The work of the group, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, is aimed at
determining the root causes and political climate that led to the deaths of
30,000 people in Peru. The commission is intent on assigning blame; its findings
can be forwarded to prosecutors for possible legal action against rights
violators.

"The truth commission in Peru can name names, institutions, and it can say
so-and-so military official killed so-and-so farmer," said Javier Ciurlizza,
executive secretary of the commission. "We decided that this will not be closed.
We need to vent these things."

How much will be vented, though, is unclear. Though the commission has ambitious
goals and a broader mandate than similar commissions in Latin America, it is
underfinanced. Only $3 million of the $10.7 million it needs to operate has been
collected, Mr. Ciurlizza said, with nearly half coming from the United States.

Investigators are also in a race against time because their work must be
completed next year, when a voluminous report tracing Peruvian violence through
three presidential administrations is to be made public.

Commission workers said the work had been overwhelming. There are thousands of
interviews to be conducted, including those of two former presidents, Fernando
Belaunde Terry and Alan Garcia Perez, under whose administrations most of the
violence took place.

The commission is also intent on studying reams of American documents, including
newly declassified diplomatic cables that show how United States officials in
Lima had received unconfirmed reports about extrajudicial killings and death
squad activities from sources in the Peruvian security services.

Commission members acknowledge that the sheer magnitude of the task might limit
what they learn.  "This is what makes us sleepless at night," Mr. Ciurlizza
said, "that if we do not do this right, then we lose the trust of the country."

The community with the most riding on the results is here in Ayacucho, a
poverty-stricken region of vast mountains and lush fields where Shining Path
embarked in 1980 on a rampage of mass killings, bombings and assassinations in
an effort to turn Peru into a radical Maoist state.

The army responded with vicious repression in which hundreds accused of being
rebel members or collaborators were killed, usually Quechua-speaking young men
who had been forced from their homes.

"They killed people who were Indians, people who did not know what the soldiers
were saying to them," said Rosio Vargas, the government's human rights ombudsman
in this province. "They were the most vulnerable people, the easiest to kill."

Now the commission is trying to give the people of Ayacucho a voice they never
had.

Detailed testimony is being collected from villagers to determine how relatives
or neighbors were killed, and by whom. Because the region is dotted with
unmarked graves -- nearly 6,000 people were "disappeared" in Peru, most from
Ayacucho and two neighboring provinces -- the commission is trying to determine
where mass graves are situated and whose bodies are in them. Remains are to be
cataloged, then turned over to relatives for reburial.

The forensic team that is handling exhumations is especially determined to find
out who gave the orders for the deaths. Jose Pablo Baraybar, who leads the team,
said many graves were concentrated around a former military base east of here,
in Totos, where prisoners were tortured and killed. Already, investigators know
about two captains who commanded soldiers in the region, officers known to
investigators only by their aliases, Jackal and Hyena.

Leonidas Pacotaype, 45, whose husband was tortured and killed by soldiers,
remembers Jackal well, saying the tall, light-skinned officer was "abusive to
our community" and "the one who sent our people to Totos, the one who made the
decisions."

Her husband, Francisco Huamani Galindo, 37, disappeared hours after kissing her
and their three children goodbye early one morning in 1983 as he left for a long
hike to a nearby village to buy provisions. Ms. Pacotaype later learned that he
had been intercepted by an army patrol, tortured with a group of 14 other men in
a town named Chiuschi and then shot dead, their bodies left in a pit that was
then covered by soldiers.

Now, she has provided the commission with everything she remembers from those
violent days -- not just what she heard about her husband's disappearance, but
what he was wearing that day, whether he had ever suffered broken bones or had
dental work, details crucial to the identification of remains.

"At the very least, I want to one day see the bones of my husband," Ms.
Pacotaype said. "I ask for justice. That is all I want."

Commission workers have tried to assure the relatives of the dead, or those who
suffered torture or other acts of violence, that they will be heard. But the
commission has also warned that not every grave will be uncovered, given limited
resources and time.

Instead, the commission hopes to unearth perhaps 20 graves, with the hope that
the findings and publicity will galvanize President Alejandro Toledo to adopt a
long-range plan to disinter bodies across the country.

That does not sit well with the victims' families, said Angelica Mendoza, who
leads an organization of mothers and wives of men who disappeared.

"There will be no justice for us, no peace for our people, until we find all the
bodies," said Ms. Mendoza, whose son, Arquimides Ascarza, 19, was taken from her
home in 1983 and never seen again. "They can not leave behind the rest. We want
all the mass graves opened."

For now, though, the villagers of Quispillacta have welcomed the commission's
work, saying the exhumation of the seven bodies buried near here has finally put
the past to rest for some families. The relatives of the dead, like Cristina
Huamani, received the bones of their loved ones in small, wooden boxes, which
they promptly reburied after holding ceremonies.

"My father was killed like a dog and buried nowhere," said Roberto Nunez
Huamani, 33, whose father, Julian Nunez, was among those who died with Ms.
Huamani's husband. "Now I feel like we have given him some justice."

A Witness Says Milosevic Knew Early About Abuses in Kosovo

BYLINE:  By MARLISE SIMONS

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 792 words

DATELINE: THE HAGUE, Feb. 18


Prosecutors at Slobodan Milosevic's war crimes trial moved swiftly today to try
to show that the ousted Yugoslav leader knew or should have known of the actions
of his underlings, did nothing and therefore bears responsibility for any
atrocities they committed.

The first witness called by the prosecution, Mahmat Bakalli, a Kosovo Albanian
who once was that province's Communist leader, said he had warned Mr. Milosevic
early on about police abuses in Kosovo.

At two meetings in mid-1998, Mr. Bakalli said, he mentioned police and army
abuses, citing a raid earlier that year on the home of a known member of the
Kosovo Liberation Army, an Albanian rebel group that had begun ambushing police
officers.

In a series of raids in the Drenica Valley, 83 Kosovar Albanians were killed,
including 24 women and children in February and March 1998, according to Human
Rights Watch.

"I said, 'You are killing civilians, you are killing women and children,' " Mr.
Bakalli testified. "Milosevic commented by saying, 'We are fighting against
terrorists.' "

Mr. Bakalli said he responded by saying, " 'But there are women and children
being killed.'

"He said, 'We gave them two hours to get away, to get out of the building.' "

Geoffrey Nice, one of the prosecutors, asked, "So he knew of this event?"

"Yes, yes," Mr. Bakalli said. "Yes. Definitely."

There are likely to be several hundred witnesses in a complicated trial that may
last up to two years before the tribunal's judges decide whether Mr. Milosevic,
60, is guilty as charged of genocide and other crimes in the three Balkan wars
-- in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo.

On Tuesday, Mr. Milosevic, who is in effect conducting his own defense, will
have the opportunity to cross-examine Mr. Bakalli.

Before the witness appeared, Mr. Milosevic ended his third day of an opening
statement. Impassioned, angry, mocking, he rejected every suggestion that he was
at all to blame for the collapse of the old Yugoslavia or the wars that
followed.

He repeatedly turned the accusation of genocide -- against Muslims in Bosnia --
on its head, suggesting that it was the Serbs who had faced "genocide."

"I have nothing to defend myself from," he said. "I can only be proud, and I can
only accuse my accusers and their bosses. I, arrested and in prison, am
nevertheless free."

His speech -- and particularly his dismissal of atrocities -- has angered many
of the war's victims.

"In my eyes, his ability to lie is just amazing," said Emir Suljagic, a Bosnian
Muslim whose father, grandfather, uncle and four cousins were among the 7,000
Bosnian Muslims massacred by Bosnian Serb forces at Srebrenica in eastern Bosnia
in 1995.

"He says every criminal usually covers a crime with another," said Mr. Suljagic,
who is helping cover the trial for a Bosnian weekly magazine. "That's him. He is
that criminal. He actually has blood running from his hands."

For the first time, Mr. Milosevic addressed the slaughter at Srebrenica, by far
the worst massacre of the war. He said that he had heard about it for the first
time from Carl Bildt, the European Union envoy to the Balkans, and that he had
immediately called Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader also indicted for
war crimes but still free.

"Karadzic, when I rang him up on the phone after I heard it happened, he swore
he knew nothing about it," he said.

The Bosnian Serb military leader, Gen. Ratko Mladic, who is also charged with
war crimes but remains free, was at Srebrenica.

Mr. Milosevic dismissed links between him and the Bosnian Serbs as "one of the
most nonsensical things that could be said here," though those alleged links are
indeed the heart of the prosecution's case. Mr. Milosevic is accused of
providing military, political and financial support to the Bosnian Serbs and
commanding Yugoslav troops who conducted brutal attacks on areas of Croatia and
Bosnia.

Today, Mr. Milosevic broke new ground by arguing that Western diplomacy helped
push Yugoslavia toward war in the 1990's. Unlike other observers of those
events, however, he did not mention Serbian nationalism and his own rise to
power.

He showed a videotaped documentary stating that Slovenia's 1990 vote to secede,
then German support of Croatia's independence in 1991 set the stage for war --
largely, he said, because it instilled fear in Serbs outside of Serbia with
memories of the hundreds of thousands Serbs massacred by the Nazi-sanctioned
Croatian Ustase movement in World War II.

He complained, too, that the news media had attacked his family -- his wife,
daughter and son, who is often reported to be involved in shady business deals
-- "in a savage way." He said the international conspiracy against him went
beyond politics: "When it comes to me," he said, "there is personal hatred."

A NATION CHALLENGED: CAPTIVES;
Red Cross Man in Guantanamo: A 'Busybody,' but Not Unwelcome

BYLINE:   By ELIZABETH BECKER

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 883 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19


As the first human rights official to inspect the American military prison at
Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, Urs Boegli was expecting a frosty, even hostile,
reception.

At the time, President Bush had refused to grant the men captured in the Afghan
war protection under the Geneva Conventions -- the accords at the heart of Mr.
Boegli's authority to ensure that the men flown to the Cuban base were being
treated humanely. But European countries were openly questioning the American
military's handling of the detainees, from blindfolding and sedating them to
holding them in metal cages.

It was up to Mr. Boegli, the chief Washington delegate of the International
Committee of the Red Cross, to thread his way through the loud debate and win
the soldiers' cooperation on the scene. To his surprise, Mr. Boegli, a
50-year-old Swiss, was welcomed as what he called "a necessary annoyance."

"They said, 'Good to have you busybodies here,' " Mr. Boegli said. "They said
they knew that if they were ever in trouble we would come and look after them,
too."

Like members of other professional armies, the American soldiers at Guantanamo
Bay look at the Geneva-based organization as an insurance policy. If they were
ever trapped in a prison in a desolate country, a visit from the Red Cross could
mean the difference between life and death.

"At a minimum our visits give the prisoner the solace of an hour's conversation
with a reasonable human being in his own language," Mr. Boegli said. "In the
most extreme cases a visit can prevent the prisoner from disappearance and
death."

Since Sept. 11 Mr. Boegli has been a very busy man.

At the start of the Afghanistan campaign, he worked with the Pentagon to ensure
that the military avoided attacking relief operations. When American jets
nonetheless bombed the Red Cross warehouses in Kabul twice in the belief they
were under the control of the Taliban, he went back to protest. The incident,
Mr. Boegli said, "reminds us we're working in a damned dangerous business."

Now he is his organization's point man overseeing how the United States treats
the first group of war captives it has detained since World War II. In Korea,
the American military handed over captured soldiers to their South Korean
allies. In Vietnam, prisoners were given to the South Vietnamese. In the Persian
Gulf war, they were turned over to Kuwait or other coalition members.

After 20 years as the quiet neutral trying to impose the rule of law in the
middle of war, Mr. Boegli has developed a dry humor about his job. He and his
fellow Red Cross delegates are the only nonpartisans to have interviewed the
more than 100 detainees at Guantanamo Bay about their treatment, but he is
forbidden to discuss those conversations.

"We have a very low profile with the press and quite a high profile with the
prisoners, and that's the way it should be," he said.

At other moments in other wars, Mr. Boegli has been less sanguine. In the early
years of the Bosnia conflict, in 1992 and 1993, his neutrality openly warred
with his sense of right and wrong. He was sent to monitor Muslim enclaves where
the only international military presence was sent to protect food aid, not the
people who were being killed in what became known as ethnic cleansing. "They
spit at you -- you're the only foreigner they see and the only thing you can do
for them is to make sure they are fed before they are shot," he said.

Mr. Boegli was headed toward a career in international business when he ran into
a fellow Swiss at a bar in Khartoum. "He was with the I.C.R.C., which I knew
nothing about, really," he said. "It sounded intriguing and within a few months
I was a relief worker."

He started in 1972 and has since had to adjust to what he calls the "bitter
complexities" of modern wars that kill far more civilians than soldiers and
where neutrality is often considered a dirty word. "It has a bad image, like
we're sitting on a fence, doing nothing," he said.

His postings have taken him to Angola, Sudan, Lebanon, Thailand, Cambodia and
now Washington, all along negotiating the release of political prisoners,
tracing lost family members, ensuring that the most vulnerable in war receive
food and medicine, training foreign military forces on the Geneva Conventions
and carrying out the bread-and-butter mission of visiting prisoners.

"We're admired -- we've won three Nobel Peace Prizes -- but we're not liked," he
said. "We have to be the one organization accepted by all sides, which means we
can't reveal what either side wants to hear, not even casualty figures."

Last year alone the organization visited 216,684 prisoners of war, civilian
internees or detainees in 68 countries, adding to the catalog of despair that
becomes the organization's confidential reports.

Yet Mr. Boegli said he had never regretted his decision to work for the Red
Cross. Not when he was surrounded by 25 men in Banja Luca, Bosnia, who
threatened to kill him if he did not get them out of harm's way. Not in 1986
when he agreed to drop one of the organization's old Swiss-bound traditions and
allow a medical doctor from the American Red Cross to work with refugees along
the Thai-Cambodian border.

The doctor, Luisa Chan, showed up, and a few years later they married. "As a
reward for my openness of mind I got my wife," he said.

CORRECTION: An article on Feb. 20 about Urs Boegli of the International
Committee of the Red Cross, the first human rights official to inspect the
conditions under which prisoners from Afghanistan are being held at the United
States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, referred incorrectly to the
precedents for the United States' holding of war captives. The prisoners in Cuba
are not the first the United States has detained since World War II. In the
Korean War, the United States and South Korea briefly maintained separate
prisoner camps before they were consolidated under the United Nations. The
Americans did not hand the captured soldiers over to the South Koreans.

The World;
The War on Terror Points a Country Toward Peace

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1033 words


JUST over the horizon from Afghanistan, another war on terror may be drawing to
a close. A week ago, the government of Sri Lanka and the Liberation Tigers of
Tamil Eelam, one of Asia's most ruthless and totalitarian rebel movements,
agreed to a firm cease-fire, with the promise of peace talks to come. It is not
a coincidence that this should occur within months of Sept. 11, many Sri Lankans
and foreign experts say. A new international environment, born of the revulsion,
shock or just plain fear engendered by attacks on the United States, has made it
possible.

The situation has parallels in Northern Ireland, where it has been widely
assumed that a decision by the Irish Republican Army in October to start turning
in arms was also related to a new atmosphere low on romanticism for violent
causes.

But the new environment works two ways. In other areas, as worried human rights
organizations point out, countries have felt emboldened to deal more harshly
with rebel movements -- from Russia to Uzbekistan, India, China, Colombia and
the Philippines. Far from pushing these conflicts toward negotiation, the
zero-tolerance approach has worked to intensify the push for a military solution
-- if only because both sides feel they can win.

Robert B. Oakley, a former American ambassador in Pakistan, Somalia and Congo
and a former State Department counterterrorism director, says the American
campaign against Al Qaeda "sort of puts a damper on a movement, and it
encourages people to take a stronger stand against it." At the same time, he
said, governments find it easier to label any rebel a terrorist. "It encourages
people to say: 'Hey! Come help me deal with my internal problems because they
all are terrorist related.' "

In Sri Lanka, there is no longer much dispute about the nature of the Tamil
rebellion, which began as a movement to rectify discrimination by the country's
ethnic Sinhalese majority and turned, under the Liberation Tigers of Tamil
Eelam, into a brutal campaign of terror that annihilated the moderate opposition
through assassination and dragooned children, who were taught to embrace
suicide. At least 65,000 people have died.

Well before Sept. 11, the United States and Britain had declared the Tigers a
terrorist organization; so had India, which once trained them but is now seeking
the extradition of their leader, Velupillai Prabakharan, for plotting the
assassination in 1991 of the Indian leader Rajiv Gandhi. Many governments have
vowed to stop the rebels' global fund-raising.

An issue more relevant now to Sri Lankans and others in need of help to achieve
peace is whether their wars on terrorism matter to important nations, most of
all the United States. Last Monday, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe appealed
for concrete outside help in keeping pressure on the Tigers to honor this truce,
and in rebuilding the economy.

Sri Lankans know there are disadvantages in being far off the beaten track from
the hunt for Al Qaeda. Not only are there no significant links to Muslim
terrorists, a Sri Lankan official said. "We don't have oil. We are of no use to
the United States or other powers." Nepal, facing a Maoist rebellion of intense
violence, is also off the American radar. Instead, American troops have rushed
to the southern Philippines to train Filipino troops battling Abu Sayaf, a less
threatening group by many measures, except for reported links to Al Qaeda.

Most recently, the Bush administration began considering military assistance to
Yemen, where suicide bombers killed 17 sailors on the destroyer Cole in 2000,
and to Georgia, where a border area is believed to be the staging ground for
Muslims who, with help from Al Qaeda fighters, are rebelling against Russian
rule in Chechnya. But the possibility of putting American troops as trainers in
that sensitive area sets off alarms in Russia -- and also among human rights
groups, who fear it would only encourage Russia in its brutal tactics against
Chechen separatists.

IN Colombia, President Andres Pastrana has abruptly abandoned a peace agreement
after provocative rebel kidnappings and scattered attacks, and last week resumed
war against leftist guerrillas allied with drug dealers. Victoria Sanford, an
anthropology professor at the University of Notre Dame who has worked in
Colombia recently, said American objectives there may actually be hindering
peace moves. "I think that Pastrana deeply cares about peace in Colombia," she
said, "but Pastrana can only implement and push for peace if he is supported by
the United States. If the United States isn't going to back up his peace
initiatives, they fall apart."

In Sri Lanka, Norway alone has come to the aid of the peace-minded government by
talking the Tigers into a truce. Now cease-fire monitors from the Nordic
countries are preparing bases, and roads are being opened to allow freer
movement by Sri Lankans who have lived in privation under Tiger rule and a
government economic embargo. That is only a small beginning, said Radikha
Coomaraswamy, director of the International Center for Ethnic Studies in
Colombo, adding that there will have to be a major international presence in
Tiger territory.

Teresita C. Schaffer, who was the American ambassador to Sri Lanka from 1992 to
1995, expressed reservations about how much foreign efforts to ban the Tigers
and stop their money-raising would hinder the group, which has a worldwide
network of front companies, its own shipping line, and a history of overrunning
Sri Lankan army bases to steal arms.

STILL, she said, the Tigers may be weakened militarily, which could explain
their inability to recapture Jaffna. "Why did they stop?" she said. "I have to
believe it was because they couldn't go on."

In the end, that may be the deciding factor in whether the no-tolerance
atmosphere toward terrorism pushes a particular conflict toward negotiation or
war.  Even if the Tigers are now hoping only to buy time for rearming and
recruitment, as many Sri Lankans fear, there is a peace constituency in the
country as well as an antiterrorism sentiment outside, Ms. Schaffer said. And in
that country, at least, the combination may make this the moment to make an
agreement stick.

in favor of peace talks by joining hands publicly, like these office workers in
Colombo, the capital. (Associated Press)

'The Lessons of Terror'

SECTION: Section 7; Column 4; Book Review Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 199 words


To the Editor:

As the executive director of Human Rights Watch, I would like to respond to
Michael Ignatieff's review of "The Lessons of Terror," by Caleb Carr (Feb. 17).
Ignatieff enters dangerous territory in suggesting that government armies are
less culpable than terrorists when they resort to the barbaric treatment of
civilians.

In his view, "aggrieved descendants" of the civilian victims "may not care
whether they were killed by terrorists or armies pursuing a just cause by unjust
means. Yet these distinctions matter intensely."

They shouldn't. One need not embrace moral relativism to recognize that even
many terrorists believe in the justice of their cause. A rule that forbids
attacks on civilians only when the cause is unjust is a thin reed on which to
build protection for civilians in time of war. Rather, as the Geneva Conventions
prescribe, intentional attacks on civilians should be prohibited regardless of
the cause.

Ignatieff correctly notes that there is a moral difference between a government
army inadvertently causing civilian deaths and a terrorist deliberately killing
civilians. But the difference is the intent, not the status, of the actor.

Kenneth Roth
New York

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

Hard-Liners Put Iranian Journalist on Trial on Spying Charges

BYLINE:  By NAZILA FATHI

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Foreign Desk; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 566 words

DATELINE: TEHRAN, March 13


A 73-year-old former journalist has gone on trial behind closed doors, charged
with espionage and threatening national security in what is considered part of a
new current of repression against intellectuals in Iran.

The former journalist, Siamak Pourzand, director of the Artistic and Cultural
Complex in Tehran, was arrested late last year by the Office of the Public
Morals Police and the State Inspectorate, a shadowy apparatus normally
responsible for dealing with religious offenses.

More than a dozen intellectuals, including a painter and filmmaker, were
summoned by the same office after Mr. Pourzand's arrest. All undertook an oath
not to reveal information about the interrogations.

A state-run newspaper, Iran, unexpectedly announced on Saturday that the trial
had begun last Thursday, just before President Mohammad Khatami's trip to
Austria and Greece. During his past visits to European countries, hard-liners
have arrested reformers back home in order to embarrass him.

The daily reported later that Mr. Pourzand admitted the nine charges against
him, confessing that he had been in contact with people close to Reza Pahlavi,
the son of the late Shah, who was ousted in 1979.

According to the newspaper, Mr. Pourzand also admitted to working for the Shah's
secret service before the revolution.

Mehrangiz Kar, Mr. Purzand's wife, said by telephone today from Washington,
where she is undergoing treatment for cancer, that she considered anything Mr.
Pourzand reportedly said to be baseless, because the statements "have been
extracted under duress."

Ms. Kar, a lawyer, spent 52 days in jail in the summer of 2000 after attending a
conference on Iran in Berlin. She said in the interview that her husband had
been interrogated after every visit he made to her in prison.

Ms. Kar said Mr. Pourzand telephoned their daughter, who is also in Washington,
on Friday, sarcastically delivering what he termed the "good news" that he had
been promised a transfer to the notorious Evin jail after his trial. "This only
suggests the extent of torture and pressure on him, that going to Evin has
become a dream and a better place for him," Ms. Kar said.

The hard-line judiciary has staged similar trials against pro-reform activists
and has publicized their confessions in the past with the apparent intention of
turning the public opinion against them.

Last year, the confessions of a student leader, Ali Afshari, were broadcast on
national news, saying he had attempted to cause unrest and overthrow the supreme
leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

This month, released from jail, he told a news conference that he had been under
"tremendous pressure" and tricked that the confession would not be broadcast. He
said he had spent 328 days of the 356 days of his detention in solitary
confinement and undergone long and intimidating interrogations.

Mr. Pourzand has been in detention since Nov. 29 and his family is not aware of
his whereabouts. His sister in Tehran, Mahin Pourzand, has seen him only at the
downtown Tehran offices of the Public Morals Police and the State Inspectorate.

Human Rights Watch condemned the trial. "The judicial authorities are making a
mockery of rule of law in Iran," said Hanny Megally, executive director of the
Middle East and North Africa division. "The Iranian authorities have given no
reason to hold Mr. Pourzand, and by law they should release him immediately."

Judge Rules The Hearing For a Detainee Must Be Open

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM with SUSAN SACHS

SECTION: Section A; Column 6; National Desk; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 551 words

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 3


A federal judge here ruled today that an immigration hearing for a local suspect
in the government's terror sweep could not be closed to reporters.

The ruling was the first in a federal court on the Justice Department's effort
to keep such cases closed and could have ramifications for hundreds of other
immigration hearings that are pending for men of Arab descent since the Sept. 11
attacks.

"Openness is necessary for the public to maintain confidence in the value and
soundness of the government's actions, as secrecy only breeds suspicion," Judge
Nancy G. Edmunds of Federal District Court ruled in rejecting the argument that
the cases should be closed for national security reasons.

In another matter involving detainees, the inspector general's office of the
Justice Department said today that it would review the conditions at one or
possibly two jails where dozens of Muslim men have been held in virtual secrecy
after their arrests.

Officials said the review would also examine whether the detainees' civil rights
have been protected during their imprisonment, including their right to legal
representation and right to know in a timely manner what, if any, charges they
face.

Paul K. Martin, a counselor to the inspector general, Glenn A. Fine, declined to
say when the inspection would begin or how long it would take. Nor would Mr.
Martin say how many federal detainees remain in the two jails selected as
candidates for inspection -- the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn and
the Passaic County Jail in Paterson, N.J.

Civil rights groups have complained that many detainees were not allowed to
contact family members or lawyers after their arrests and that they have been
held under especially harsh conditions for people charged only with minor
immigration violations.

An investigation by Amnesty International, based on the accounts of former
prisoners and the few lawyers who have visited the jails, also found evidence
that some prisoners have been kept in solitary confinement for long periods or
were subjected to verbal or physical abuse.

As of mid-February, Amnesty International reported, 327 of the 1,200 people
detained after Sept. 11 were still in government custody.

The ruling on open immigration hearings was in the case of Rabih Haddad, a
native of Lebanon and resident of Ann Arbor, Mich., who faces an immigration
hearing on April 10. Mr. Haddad is a founder of the Global Relief Foundation, an
Islamic charity that has come under federal scrutiny for possible links to
terror groups.

Officials at the American Civil Liberties Union called the ruling an important
victory for civil rights in the first federal court decision concerning the
government's actions following Sept. 11.

"The broader significance of the decision is that the court sent a clear message
that the judiciary should not just rubber-stamp the government's Sept. 11
policies," said Lee Gelernt, senior staff lawyer for the group's Immigrants'
Rights Project.

The Justice Department may appeal the case to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, before Mr. Haddad's hearing next week.

Barbara Comstock, a spokeswoman for the department, said the ruling was being
reviewed. "No decision has been made at this time as to what our next step will
be," she said.

The World;
The Helping Hand Gets Limp Shakes

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 1194 words

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia


IT should have been easy. The Bush administration wanted to expand its war on
terror to Asia, to places on whose soil bad guys with links to Al Qaeda might be
operating. Indonesia and the Philippines were considered the two obvious
targets: countries friendly to the United States that needed help. Since to
Washington's way of thinking this is war, the recipe called for American
military assistance.

But extending a friendly hand has raised suspicions, rekindled old debates about
colonization in the Philippines and set off accusations of meddling in
Indonesia.

That the leaders of both countries are new to power and are strongly backed by
their military forces has presented its own set of problems.

But there is also a cautionary lesson for the United States: American military
power isn't always greeted with a welcome mat, even in nations that the United
States believes want to do the right thing. In many places history is freighted
with bad memories of what American military power can bring.

The Philippines is a treaty ally of the United States and is now led by a
pro-American president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, a graduate of Georgetown
University. But even there, the politics of putting American boots on the ground
has proven delicate and divisive. In the closing years of the cold war, American
bases were widely resented; America had, after all, been close to the corrupt
dictator Ferdinand Marcos.

Even today, the departure of the American military from Subic Bay in 1991
remains a scar on the Filipino psyche, and the "Yankee go home" cries from back
then have not been transformed into "Yankee hurry back."

Mrs. Arroyo, the only leader in Asia to invite American troops since Sept. 11,
argues that she took political risks in accepting President Bush's offer of
training for her army and help in hunting a gang of Muslim kidnappers, known as
the Abu Sayyaf, on the southern island of Basilan. (Mrs. Arroyo had to curb
President Bush's enthusiasm for American combat troops, pointing out that the
Filipino constitution forbade such intervention.)

Since arriving in the Philippines in February, 600 American troops -- 160 of
them Special Operations forces based on Basilan -- have dealt as much with
political fears about their presence as with military matters. When two American
soldiers with M-16 rifles were photographed outside a bank while their
compatriots withdrew money, screaming headlines demanded to know: What were
armed American soldiers in civilian clothes doing on a Filipino city street?

So far, the American soldiers have been passive as the Filipino army continues
its effort, now six years old, to stamp out the Abu Sayyaf.

Mrs. Arroyo, it turns out, wants it both ways. While she is happy to have the
Americans on her territory, she doesn't want them to upstage the Philippines'
soldiers. And the American troops go along, knowing they could harm Mrs.
Arroyo's political fortunes -- for example, if a Filipino child were killed
accidentally by an American soldier, or if there were a public spat with the
Filipino military.

Political considerations aside, the American troops do not have a lot of choice.
The Philippine military is insisting that it is in charge of the efforts to
defeat the Abu Sayyaf, and that the American military stay in the background
during operations. So the Americans have yet to go deep into the jungles of
Basilan with Filipino troops.

But the Filipino military suffers from chronic divisions among its services.
When the army and the Marines compete to claim victory over the Abu Sayyaf, it
hampers the ability of both to stage successful maneuvers, American officials
say.

DESPITE the frustration, in private the Americans are not complaining too much.
They are discouraged that an American missionary couple, Martin and Gracia
Burnham, who have been in the hands of the Abu Sayyaf for 10 months, have not
been rescued. But, they say, the United States needs the Philippines for the
long haul. If the southern Philippines, where Muslim separatists have long
operated, can be stabilized, the islands there could make a perfect future
listening post, and good jumping off point, for guarding the whole range of
American interests in the Pacific.

Indonesia presents a different picture. President Megawati Sukarnoputri, like
Mrs. Arroyo, has been in office since last year and she too visited President
Bush after Sept. 11.

But she is a far more reluctant suitor when military aid is concerned. She leads
a country -- the world's most populous Muslim nation -- that prides itself on
neutrality these days. American assistance is looked upon with such distrust
that the Indonesian military turned down an offer from the Pentagon to deliver
aid during floods in Jakarta in February. The Pentagon had a major training role
in Indonesia during the cold war, but became estranged in the 1990's over the
question of Indonesian human rights abuses.

Any hint of an American presence in Indonesia today would probably end Mrs.
Megawati's young presidency, and for that reason Washington officials say they
would not consider barging in. In the last month, in fact, the Bush
administration has tempered its description of the threat in Indonesia,
asserting that it is a potential, rather than a current, haven.

Nevertheless, Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul D. Wolfowitz, who was ambassador
in Indonesia for three years, has made no secret of his desire to help the armed
forces against what he sees as a burgeoning band of Islamic extremists. Mr.
Wolfowitz has spoken of helping the Indonesians to form an internal peacekeeping
force. He is not contemplating the presence of American combat troops, but
rather training for the army and the police, he said.

BUT the army's human rights record presents a significant stumbling block. A
1999 law whose author was Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, forbids
American assistance to the Indonesian army until it brings to account officers
responsible for more than 100 civilian deaths during a rampage of
military-backed militia in East Timor that year.

Many in the Bush administration would like to get around this restriction,
arguing that reform is not possible unless the United States guides it by
renewing ties with the military. American officials have tried to encourage Mrs.
Megawati to be more open-minded by asserting that Congress is not demanding the
wholesale prosecution of the Indonesian Army but, simply, a serious effort
toward reform. Still, a trial here involving human rights in East Timor, which
the Indonesian government has billed as its answer to Washington's concerns,
shows little sign of satisfying Congress.

In a show of sympathy for Mrs. Megawati, Senators Ted Stevens, Republican of
Alaska, and Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, told her during a visit last
week that they agreed with her that the military was the most important
institution in the country. They told her they opposed the Congressional
restrictions at the time of their passage but warned her that as much as they
wanted to provide training, they could not encourage policies that flouted the
law. President Megawati listened politely, but made no promises.

World Briefing World: Led By China, Executions Soar

BYLINE:  Reuters

SECTION: Section A; Column 4; Foreign Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 76 words


Governments executed at least 3,048 of their citizens last year, more than
double the number in 2000, the human rights group Amnesty International said.
China, which is cracking down on crime, accounted for 81 percent of the total,
executing at least 2,468 people. Of the 31 countries using the death penalty,
Iran ranked second with 139 reported executions and Saudi Arabia third with 79.
The United States was fourth with 66 executions, the group said.
