Supreme Court Allows Secrecy To Stand in Deportation Cases

SECTION: Section A; Column 5; National Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 410 words


The United States Supreme Court granted a Justice Department request yesterday
to allow secret deportation hearings for people arrested after Sept. 11 to
continue while the government appeals a federal judge's order to open the
hearings.

It was the justices' first action addressing any of the government's
antiterrorism policies since the attacks. Without comment, the court agreed to
stay the order to open the hearings, issued on May 28 by Judge John J. Bissell
of Federal District Court in Newark, who found the secret hearings
unconstitutional.

A similar stay motion had been rejected by Judge Bissell, and by a panel of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia. An appeal
by the government to overturn Judge Bissell's order is pending before the Court
of Appeals and could ultimately put the case back before the Supreme Court.

The government has argued that opening the deportation hearings could compromise
its investigation of terrorist activity. Judge Bissell's order would allow for
secret hearings, but on a case-by-case basis after a national security interest
has been demonstrated. The government has argued that even discussing national
security interests could result in compromising revelations.

The case began with a lawsuit filed on First Amendment grounds by the American
Civil Liberties Union on behalf of The New Jersey Law Journal and the North
Jersey Media Group, a newspaper publisher. They had sought access to the
hearings after the nation's chief immigration judge, Michael Creppy, ordered
them closed in September at the direction of Attorney General John Ashcroft.

Lee Gelernt, the Civil Liberties Union lawyer handing the suit, said yesterday
that the group was disappointed by the Supreme Court's action. "It's hard to
read anything definitively into a one-line order without an opinion," Mr.
Gelernt said. "We continue to believe that we will prevail on the merits."

A spokeswoman for the Justice Department said she did not know whether hearings
would continue in secret during the appeal.

At least one hearing had been scheduled to be held openly under Judge Bissell's
order, on June 17 in Newark. But that hearing was postponed indefinitely by the
Board of Immigration Appeal, a quasi-judicial body within the Justice
Department. Regis Fernandez, a lawyer for two Jordanian cousins whose cases were
to have been heard, said he expected that the hearing would now be rescheduled,
in secret.

Aid for Afghan Women

SECTION: Section 4; Column 5; Editorial Desk; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 135 words


To the Editor:

"In Afghanistan, Where Pregnancy Is Still a Minefield" (Women's Health section,
June 23) highlights the effects of pervasive discrimination on women's lives and
health. Declarations adopted at global conferences and by United Nations
agencies have shown growing recognition that survival of pregnancy and
childbirth is a matter of human rights.

It is tragic that the Taliban's history of discrimination is echoed in the aid
policies of donor governments. International donors and the Afghan government
should invest in women's reproductive health while recognizing women as equal
partners in the political, economic and social life of Afghanistan.

LAURA KATZIVE
New York, June 24, 2002

The writer is legal adviser for global projects, international program, Center
for Reproductive Law and Policy.

Against Humanity

SECTION: Section 7; Column 5; Book Review Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 116 words


To the Editor:

Joseph Kanon's review of William F. Buckley Jr.'s "Nuremberg" (June 9) asserts
that the trials "grappled with . . . the very definition of 'war crimes.'

" In fact, war crimes were easy to define and punish because the rules of land
warfare had been developing over more than 500 years of armed combat.

What the Allies grappled with was the need to address Germany's conduct off the
battlefield, especially its treacherous aggression and the persecution of its
own citizens in the 1930's. The answer was the novel charges of crimes against
humanity and the crime against peace, which until then had been only vaguely
envisioned as justiciable crimes.

Allan A. Ryan Jr.
Cambridge, Mass.
